awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Mechanisms of CO2 Adsorption in Amine-immobilized Porous Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM faculty at HBCUs to pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at their home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Fayetteville State University (FSU), will conduct research aimed at addressing one of the most pressing environmental concerns of our age: the escalating level of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), which is a major greenhouse gas largely correlated to the combustion of fossil fuels. For the foreseeable future, it seems that the ever-growing energy demand will most likely necessitate more consumption of these indispensable sources of energy. Therefore, it is strategically important to develop technologies for Carbon Capture, Usage and Storage (CCUS). Currently, aqueous amine solution is the most advanced technology for carbon capture. However, the use of aqueous amine solution suffers from several significant drawbacks, including apparatus corrosion and high regeneration cost. These disadvantages can be alleviated if we graft amine into porous solid matrix instead of mixing with water. This project aims at developing novel amine-grafted porous organic polymers for efficient carbon capture. We expect two major benefits for our designed materials: one is noncorrosive. Amines are grafted inside the porous solid matrix without direct contact the apparatus. The other is energy efficient. Water has one of the highest heat capacities. It costs a lot more energy to heat aqueous solution than porous solid in a temperature swing process. The successful implementation of this proposed research will enhance our international competitiveness in carbon capture technology.

The scientific challenges for amine-grafted porous materials to become an economically viable technology for carbon capture are their CO2 loading, recyclability, and manufacturing costs. The better understanding of adsorption-desorption mechanisms of CO2 in amine-grafted porous materials is one of the key factors which will help us design and synthesize such materials to reach maximum CO2 loading with optimized energy efficiency. We propose several strategies to build porous polymeric platforms to study the structure-property correlations between amines and CO2 molecules. First, we build anchors in the porous platforms, then we use these anchors to attach amines of different lengths. The number of amines that could be incorporated is largely dependent upon the number of installed anchors; therefore, high concentration and even distribution of anchors inside the porous platforms ensure the maximum amine loading afterwards. The proposed research will advance our understanding of the CO2 adsorption-desorption mechanisms in amine-grafted porous materials at the molecular level. The knowledge generated will guide the development of such materials of high CO2 loading with optimized energy efficiency. The proposed research will also allow the PI to work with two to three undergraduate researchers each year over a three-year course. All of them will obtain extensive training in experimental design and implementation, data collection and analysis, results presentation and publication, etc. Such experiences will boost their competency and prepare them for graduate schools or professional workforces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit of the project 

The rising level of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas, chiefly produced from the global increase in the combustion of fossil fuels is perhaps the most urgent environmental issue today.  The rise in these global atmospheric CO2 levels seems to be unabated for the foreseeable future due to a growing fossil fuel consumption to satiate the energy demand from an increasing global population.   It is thus of great importance to develop Carbon Capture, Usage, and Storage (CCUS) technologies to offset these increased CO2 emissions. In this work, we focused primarily on studying novel two-dimensional transition metal carbides known as MXenes for their application to CO2 capture and then assessing how the intercalation of amine-containing compounds affected the CO2adsorption capacity of these materials.  Firstly, we investigated how the etching procedure used to prepare Ti3C2Tx and Ti2CTx MXene influenced the morphology, specific surface area, and CO2 adsorption capacity. Secondly, we studied how the intercalation of amine-containing molecules affected the morphology, specific surface area, and CO2 adsorption capacity. Furthermore, we also studied the morphology, structure, surface area, heat of adsorption, and adsorption capacity of CO2 in one-dimensional lepidocrocite titania (1DL TiO2).  The following findings were revealed from the project:

1. The etching process in the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx MXene from the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase affects the morphology and thus the specific surface area and CO2 adsorption capacity.  The milder hydrothermal etching process involving an aqueous solution of lithium fluoride (LiF) in hydrochloric acid (HCl) seems to favor MXenes with a greater CO2 adsorption capacity than for MXenes produced from the harsher direct hydrofluoric acid (HF) method.

2. Amine-containing compounds were successfully intercalated between the layers of two-dimensional Ti3C2Tx MXene as evidence by a shifting of the (002) peak in the powder x-ray diffraction spectra to lower scattering angles and resulting in an increase in the c-lattice parameter. However, the intercalation of amine-containing compounds did not increase the CO2 adsorption capacity, likely due to bonding of the amine group with the surface-terminated oxide (-O) and hydroxide (-OH) Tx layer and blocking of the micropores in the MXene by the amine-containing molecules to hinder CO2 uptake.

3. An enhancement in ultra-micropores (<1 nm diameter) is essential for increased CO2 uptake at low partial pressures in MXenes and in one-dimensional lepidocrocite titania (1DL), and an increased CO2 adsorption capacity does not simply result from an increase in surface area.  Since the synthesis of 1DL titania involves a “bottoms-up” approach, similar to that in metal organic frameworks (MOFs), there is greater control of the production of ultra-micropores compared to the “top-down” synthesis preparation of MXenes via the selective etching of MAX phase materials.

4. From the CO2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for 1DL samples, the heat of adsorption analysis from the desorption branch (80 kJ/mol) is greater than that obtained from the adsorption branch (40 kJ/mol), indicating that the CO2 is interacting with the 1DL titania surfaces.

Broader impacts of the project

The project focused on enhancing diversity in STEM education and training by engaging underrepresented undergraduate students in research and scholarly activities. Twelve students, including eleven undergraduate students and one high school student, were involved in the research project. Out of these twelve, ten were female, eight were African American, and three were Hispanic. These participants were trained in sample synthesis and characterization techniques, surface area determination, CO2 adsorption capacity, as well as data analysis, oral and poster presentations, and manuscript writing. Six undergraduate students co-authored published journals. Six students presented their research work at conferences and symposia and three students completed summer internships at research-intensive universities. To date, three undergraduate students are pursing graduate study at prestigious universities and two current students are applying graduate programs.   This grant enhanced the research capacity of the university by the purchase of a gas adsorption analyzer, which was also to facilitate research collaboration within the department and to train students in surface area determination techniques in the physical chemistry laboratory. The project provided a unique opportunity for undergraduate students to be involved in progressive research in the field of carbon capture and to be mentored to academic success through research, presentation, and publication training. This work provides a better understanding of how sample preparation affects the morphology and formation of ultra-micropores that enhance the CO2 adsorption capacity in bare and amine-intercalated Ti3C2Tx and Ti2CTx MXenes and 1DL titania. 

The product of the project includes six peer-reviewed publications and more than twelve scholarly presentations at conferences, workshops and symposia.
